Sir James Hopwood Jeans, English astronomical physicist and
mathematician, will present an illustrated lecture, dealing with modern
problems of astronomy, Friday, at
5 p. m., in Latrobe Hall, room 120.
The degree of doctor of laws will
be conferred upon Sir James by Dr.
Joseph S. Ames, president of the
Hopkins, at 4:30 P. M., prior to
the lecture which he is to present.
Ceremonies are to take place in
the Gilman Memorial Room.

Knighted Three Years Ago

He was knighted only three years
ago in England. At Cambridge
University, from where he was
graduated, Jeans was Stokes lecturer
in applied mathematics. In Princeton University he was for some
time professor of applied mathematics. Since 1919 he has been secretary of the Royal Society.

New O.D.K. Officers
Chosen At Meeting
Kneip, Guild. Ley, Gutman Are Elected Committee On Campus Grounds
Meeting, Reports Progress

Omicron Delta Kappa, honorary
fraternity at the Hopkins, elected
new officers for next year. \Valter
Kneip was elected president; Lorne
Guild, vice-president; Ronald Levy,
secretary; and Isador Gutman,
treasurer.
All records of previous years'
activities of the 0. D. K. were
turned over to the newly elected officers.
At the meeting, which was the
final one of the year, a committee
reported that progress is being made
in arranging for the sqding of bare
spots on the campus.

Play U. of 1'. Saturday

On Saturday the Hopkins netmen are scheduled to play the University of Pennsylvania team on the
Riyer Field courts in Philadelphia.
Although the Penn team is reputed
to be quite strong this year, the
Jay racquet-wielders will be out to
avenge the defeat administered by
N. Y. U.

Both "Lie" About
Campus, Says Prof.
A professor at Susquehanna University recently gave his interpretation of the similarity of a college
campus and a college catalogue. According to the pedaogue in question,
they both "lie" about the college.
Well, well, what do you know about
that. Smart boys, these professors.

in good condition and making the appearance of the campus as pleasing
as possible, but we are very lax in the
way in which we handle our roads.
We hire men whose job it is to go
about filling in the ruts and holes in
our roads and smoothing out the
humps in the center.
Two hours after they have completed their work, the condition of
the roads is just as bads as it was before they started. It seems to us a
waste of both time and money to have
these men fill in the holes with ashes.
What we suggest would be that the
University take enough money out
of its coffers to put down some respectable drives that we would
be proud of and that would fit in
with the rest of the campus. In their
present condition they are a disgrace
to the college. After a rain the roads
would remind an onlooker of the
Thousand Islands. A modern drive
on the campus would improve the
looks of the place 100 per cent.
Our predecessors have written editorials in the same vein as the above
one. A strong cry in the present era
is to be modern and to make improvements along all lines when the results
will mean progress. We sincerely
believe that such a move would be a
step in the right direction.
We hope that these meager
thoughts will not fall on barren
ground like those of our predecessors,
but that these suggestions will flail
upon fertile soil and will take root
and blossom forth into a bounteous
harvest.
R. N.

EDITORIALS

(From the Sou'Wester)

The time for election of the officers for the student body for next
year is at hand. For the last few
years the word -election" has been
sy-nonymous with -politics" on the
Groups
Southwestern campus.
have banded together and swapped
officers like a band of robbers dividing up the spoils. And they have
been robbers, for anything that is
done to prevent a clean, honest, unprejudiced, free vote, is dishonesty
in one of its worse forms.
It is time that this school wake
up to itself and realize that honor
and reputation can not be sacrificed
for a few offices. Have things
reached such a state that organizations can "rate" on the campus
through holding offices?
We believe that all of the groups
on the campus are ready to back a
clean election. We believe that public sentiment is strong against a
repetition of the elections of the
last years.

Among the jobs obtained for Yale
students by the Employment Council
up at the New Haven shrine of the
higher things in life is that of pallbearer for which they are paid a fee
of two dollars.

The morale of the following tale
is, "Thou shalt never boast of thy
misdeeds." The dear little freshlings at Dickinson let the world in
on the secret that they had made a
more or less complete wreck of
every freshman rule. This goaded
to righteous ire, not to mention
wrath and indignation, the bally old
sophomore pep commiltee—don't
you know—took out their trusty old
Gillette's and shaved the yearlings'
inferior heads.
* * *
A student at a certain university
was asked why the Persians lost the
battle of Salamis. He replied: "It
was lost because the Persians lacked
three ships, statesmanship, marksmanship, and leadership." (Editorial comment: Thus a new school
in historical study begins.)

The purpose of Pi Delta Epsilon
is to recognize journalistic ability
and to promote interest in publications. A chapter existed at the
Hopkins several years ago but the
members relinquished their charter.
Installation of the new chapter
will take place before the end of
the current semester it was declared by members. Dean Henry
Grattan Doyle of George Washington University, grand national
secretary of the fraternity, will officiate at the ceremonies.

The fellowship was awarded by

Institute of International Education, Miss Fifi Colimore, secretary
to the Italian consul located in Baltimore, said late yesterday. Miss
Colimore explained that the fellowships are exchange grants—that
the United States offers scholarship for study by Italian students
in American universities, and that
Italy gives scholarships to American for work in Italian institutions.

St. Johns' College Student Discusses
Dread Disease, Athlete's
Foot

A recent meeting of the Osler
Pre-Medical Club of St. Johns College was featured by a speech by
one of the youthful members on the
subject of the dread disease of
athletes' foot. It was treated with
extreme thoroughness as the speaker
had had, so he said, considerable
personal experience with the malady.
He declared vehemently that most
of the widely advertised cures for
athletes' foot are the bunk. He concluded with the stirring assertion
that "the dreaded national malady
must go."

Knighted Three Years Ago

He was knighted only three years
ago in England. At Cambridge
University, from where he was
graduated, Jeans was Stokes lecturer
in applied mathematics. In Princeton University he was for some
time professor of applied mathematics. Since 1919 he has been secretary of the Royal Society.

Chosen At Meeting
Kneip, Guild. Ley, Gutman Are Elected Committee On Campus Grounds
Meeting, Reports Progress

Omicron Delta Kappa, honorary
fraternity at the Hopkins, elected
new officers for next year. \Valter
Kneip was elected president; Lorne
Guild, vice-president; Ronald Levy,
secretary; and Isador Gutman,
treasurer.
All records of previous years'
activities of the 0. D. K. were
turned over to the newly elected officers.
At the meeting, which was the
final one of the year, a committee
reported that progress is being made
in arranging for the sqding of bare
spots on the campus.

in good condition and making the appearance of the campus as pleasing
as possible, but we are very lax in the
way in which we handle our roads.
We hire men whose job it is to go
about filling in the ruts and holes in
our roads and smoothing out the
humps in the center.
Two hours after they have completed their work, the condition of
the roads is just as bads as it was before they started. It seems to us a
waste of both time and money to have
these men fill in the holes with ashes.
What we suggest would be that the
University take enough money out
of its coffers to put down some respectable drives that we would
be proud of and that would fit in
with the rest of the campus. In their
present condition they are a disgrace
to the college. After a rain the roads
would remind an onlooker of the
Thousand Islands. A modern drive
on the campus would improve the
looks of the place 100 per cent.
Our predecessors have written editorials in the same vein as the above
one. A strong cry in the present era
is to be modern and to make improvements along all lines when the results
will mean progress. We sincerely
believe that such a move would be a
step in the right direction.
We hope that these meager
thoughts will not fall on barren
ground like those of our predecessors,
but that these suggestions will flail
upon fertile soil and will take root
and blossom forth into a bounteous
harvest.
R. N.

The time for election of the officers for the student body for next
year is at hand. For the last few
years the word -election" has been
sy-nonymous with -politics" on the
Groups

It is time that this school wake
up to itself and realize that honor
and reputation can not be sacrificed
for a few offices. Have things
reached such a state that organizations can "rate" on the campus
through holding offices?
We believe that all of the groups
on the campus are ready to back a
clean election. We believe that public sentiment is strong against a
repetition of the elections of the
last years.

Received Autographed Copy

To Dr. Jacobs, in October, 1905,
was presented a copy of the sixth
edition of Practice In Medicine,
autographed by Osler. This was the
147th of the 105,000 copies published of the book. A first edition

volume of Contributions To Medical

arranged by a committee composed
of American and British medical
men. Dr. Jacobs was the secretary
of the committee at the time.

The purpose of Pi Delta Epsilon
is to recognize journalistic ability
and to promote interest in publications. A chapter existed at the
Hopkins several years ago but the
members relinquished their charter.
Installation of the new chapter
will take place before the end of
the current semester it was declared by members. Dean Henry
Grattan Doyle of George Washington University, grand national
secretary of the fraternity, will officiate at the ceremonies.

The fellowship was awarded by
the Italian government through the
Institute of International Education, Miss Fifi Colimore, secretary
to the Italian consul located in Baltimore, said late yesterday. Miss
Colimore explained that the fellowships are exchange grants—that
the United States offers scholarship for study by Italian students
in American universities, and that
Italy gives scholarships to American for work in Italian institutions.

Miss Leona Feller, graduate
student in the Department of History, has been elected national
president of Phi Delta Gamma, the
only graduate student sorority in
the United States, it was declared.
The election of Miss Fehler was
held at a recent convention of the
sorority in Washington, D. C., at
which delegates from all chapters
were present. The new officers
were installed at a banquet held
in the Grace Dodge Hotel.

St. Johns' College Student Discusses
Dread Disease, Athlete's
Foot

A recent meeting of the Osler
Pre-Medical Club of St. Johns College was featured by a speech by
one of the youthful members on the
subject of the dread disease of
athletes' foot. It was treated with
extreme thoroughness as the speaker
had had, so he said, considerable
personal experience with the malady.
He declared vehemently that most
of the widely advertised cures for
athletes' foot are the bunk. He concluded with the stirring assertion
that "the dreaded national malady
must go."
